ğŸ“– Greshamâ€™s law, observation in economics that â€œbad money drives out good.â€ More exactly, if coins containing metal of different value have the same value as legal tender, the coins composed of the cheaper metal will be used for payment, while those made of more expensive metal will be hoarded or exported and thus tend to disappear from circulation

entry.title: Polar code & channel polarization
entry.content:
æåŒ–ç ï¼ˆPolar codeï¼‰æ˜¯ä¸€ç§å‰å‘é”™è¯¯æ›´æ­£ç¼–ç æ–¹å¼ï¼Œç”¨äºè®¯å·ä¼ è¾“ã€‚

æ„é€ çš„æ ¸å¿ƒæ˜¯é€šè¿‡ä¿¡é“æåŒ–ï¼ˆchannel polarizationï¼‰å¤„ç†ï¼Œåœ¨ç¼–ç ä¾§é‡‡ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ä½¿å„ä¸ªå­ä¿¡é“å‘ˆç°å‡ºä¸åŒçš„å¯é æ€§ï¼Œå½“ç é•¿æŒç»­å¢åŠ æ—¶ï¼Œéƒ¨åˆ†ä¿¡é“å°†è¶‹å‘äºå®¹é‡è¿‘äº 1 çš„å®Œç¾ä¿¡é“ï¼ˆæ— è¯¯ç ï¼‰ï¼Œå¦ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ä¿¡é“è¶‹å‘äºå®¹é‡æ¥è¿‘äº 0 çš„çº¯å™ªå£°ä¿¡é“ï¼Œé€‰æ‹©åœ¨å®¹é‡æ¥è¿‘äº 1 çš„ä¿¡é“ä¸Šç›´æ¥ä¼ è¾“ä¿¡æ¯ä»¥é€¼è¿‘ä¿¡é“å®¹é‡ï¼Œæ˜¯é¦–ä¸ªè¢«è¯æ˜èƒ½å¤Ÿè¾¾åˆ°é¦™å†œæé™çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

åœ¨è§£ç ä¾§ï¼ŒæåŒ–åçš„ä¿¡é“å¯ç”¨ç®€å•çš„é€æ¬¡å¹²æ‰°æŠµæ¶ˆè§£ç çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä»¥è¾ƒä½çš„å¤æ‚åº¦è·å¾—ä¸æœ€å¤§ä¼¼ç„¶è§£ç ç›¸è¿‘çš„æ€§èƒ½ã€‚

å¦‚æœä½ æ²¡æœ‰ä¿¡æ¯è®ºåŸºç¡€ï¼Œè¯·å…ˆçœ‹ Information Theory Primer ç« èŠ‚ã€‚

# Introduction

Polar codes were introduced by Erdal ArÄ±kan in 2009 and they provide the first deterministic construction of capacity-achieving codes for binary memoryless symmetric (BMS) channels.

Notice that there is only one channel to transmission data, in order to facilitate the understanding, we logically separate one channel to two channel.

In particular, consider a setup where (U1,U2)(U_1, U_2)(U1â€‹,U2â€‹) are two equiprobable bits that are encoded into (X1,X2)=(U1âŠ•U2,U2)(X_1, X_2) = (U_1 âŠ• U_2, U_2)(X1â€‹,X2â€‹)=(U1â€‹âŠ•U2â€‹,U2â€‹). Then, (X1,X2)(X_1, X_2)(X1â€‹,X2â€‹) are mapped to (Y1,Y2)(Y_1, Y_2)(Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹) by two independent BMS channels with transition probabilities P(Y1=yâˆ£X1=x)=P(Y2=yâˆ£X2=x)=W(yâˆ£x)P(Y_1 = y | X_1 = x) = P(Y_2 = y | X_2 = x) = W(y|x)P(Y1â€‹=yâˆ£X1â€‹=x)=P(Y2â€‹=yâˆ£X2â€‹=x)=W(yâˆ£x). Since the mapping from (U1,U2)(U_1, U_2)(U1â€‹,U2â€‹) to (X1,X2)(X_1, X_2)(X1â€‹,X2â€‹) is invertible, one finds that

I(U1,U2;Y1,Y2)=I(X1,X2;Y1,Y2)=I(X1;Y1)+I(X2;Y2)=2I(W)I(U_1,U_2;Y_1,Y_2) = I(X_1,X_2;Y_1,Y_2) = I(X_1; Y_1) + I(X_2;Y_2) = 2I(W) I(U1â€‹,U2â€‹;Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹)=I(X1â€‹,X2â€‹;Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹)=I(X1â€‹;Y1â€‹)+I(X2â€‹;Y2â€‹)=2I(W)

where C=I(X1;Y1)=I(W)C = I(X_1; Y_1) = I(W)C=I(X1â€‹;Y1â€‹)=I(W) is the capacity of symmetric BMS channel because X1X_1X1â€‹ is equiprobable and

I(W)â‰œâˆ‘yW(yâˆ£0)log2[W(yâˆ£0)/(12W(yâˆ£0)+12W(yâˆ£1))]=I(X1;Y1)I(W) \triangleq \displaystyle\sum_y W(y|0)log_{2}[{W(y|0)/({\frac{1}{2}}W(y|0) + \frac{1}{2}W(y|1))}] = I(X_1;Y_1) I(W)â‰œyâˆ‘â€‹W(yâˆ£0)log2â€‹[W(yâˆ£0)/(21â€‹W(yâˆ£0)+21â€‹W(yâˆ£1))]=I(X1â€‹;Y1â€‹)

Thus, the transformation (X1,X2)=(U1âŠ•U2,U2)(X_1, X_2) = (U_1 âŠ• U_2, U_2)(X1â€‹,X2â€‹)=(U1â€‹âŠ•U2â€‹,U2â€‹) preserves the sum capacity of the system.

Also, the chain rule decomposition

I(U1,U2;Y1,Y2)=I(U1;Y1,Y2)+I(U2;Y1,Y2âˆ£U1)=2I(W)I(U_1, U_2; Y_1, Y_2) = I(U_1; Y_1, Y_2) + I(U_2; Y_1, Y_2|U_1) = 2I(W) I(U1â€‹,U2â€‹;Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹)=I(U1â€‹;Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹)+I(U2â€‹;Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹âˆ£U1â€‹)=2I(W)

implies that one can also achieve the rate 2I(W)2I(W)2I(W) using two steps. First, information is transmitted through the first virtual channel Wâˆ’:U1â†’(Y1,Y2)W^- : U_1 â†’ (Y_1, Y_2)Wâˆ’:U1â€‹â†’(Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹). By coding over multiple channel uses, one can achieve any rate up to I(U1;Y1,Y2)I(U_1; Y_1, Y_2)I(U1â€‹;Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹). If all the U1U_1U1â€‹â€™s are known from the first stage, then one can decode the information transmitted through the second virtual channel W+:U2â†’(Y1,Y2,U1)W^+ : U_2 â†’ (Y_1, Y_2, U_1)W+:U2â€‹â†’(Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹,U1â€‹). Again, coding allows one to achieve any rate up to I(U2;Y1,Y2âˆ£U1)I(U_2; Y_1, Y_2|U_1)I(U2â€‹;Y1â€‹,Y2â€‹âˆ£U1â€‹).

If one chooses convolutional codes with sequential decoding, however, the expected decoding-complexity per bit becomes unbounded for rates above the computational cutoff rate

R0(W)=1âˆ’log2(1+Z(W))R_0(W) = 1 - log_{2}{(1 + Z(W))} R0â€‹(W)=1âˆ’log2â€‹(1+Z(W))

where

Z(W)â‰œâˆ‘yW(yâˆ£0)W(yâˆ£1)Z(W) \triangleq \displaystyle\sum_y \sqrt{W(y|0)W(y|1) } Z(W)â‰œyâˆ‘â€‹W(yâˆ£0)W(yâˆ£1)â€‹

is the Bhattacharyya parameter of the channel . ArÄ±kanâ€™s key observation was that, while the sum capacity of the two virtual channels is preserved, the sum cutoff rate satisfies

R0(W+)+R0(Wâˆ’)â‰¥2R0(W)R_0(W^+) + R_0(W^-) â‰¥ 2R_0(W) R0â€‹(W+)+R0â€‹(Wâˆ’)â‰¥2R0â€‹(W)

with equality R0(W)âˆˆ0,1R_0(W) âˆˆ {0, 1}R0â€‹(W)âˆˆ0,1. Thus, repeated transformations of this type cause the implied virtual channels to polarize into extremal channels whose capacities approach 0 or 1. But, for these extremal channels, coding is trivial and one either sends an information bit or a dummy bit. From a theoretical point of view, polar codes are beautifully simple. Practically, they approach capacity rather slowly as their blocklength increases. Still, based on recent advances, they have been chosen as the short-block codes for the 5G standard.

# Information Theory Primer

# Discrete Random variables

A discrete random variable XXX is completely defined by the set of values it can take, $\mathcal{X} $ , which we assume to be a finite set, and its probability distribution {p(x)}xâˆˆX\left \{p(x) \right \}_{x \in \mathcal{X} }{p(x)}xâˆˆXâ€‹ .

Definition. The value p(x)p(x)p(x) is the probability that the random variable XXX takes the value xxx. The probability distribution p : Xâ†’[0,1]\mathcal{X} â†’ [0, 1]Xâ†’[0,1] must satisfy the normalization condition:

âˆ‘xâˆˆÏ‡p(x)=1\displaystyle\sum_{x \in \chi} p(x) = 1 xâˆˆÏ‡âˆ‘â€‹p(x)=1

We shall denote by P(A)\mathbb{P}(A)P(A) the probability of an event $A \subseteq \mathcal{X} $, so that p(x)=P(X=x)p(x) = \mathbb{P}(X=x)p(x)=P(X=x)

# Self-information

Claude Shannon's definition of self-information was chosen to meet several axioms:

  1. An event with probability 100% is perfectly unsurprising and yields no information.
  2. The less probable an event is, the more surprising it is and the more information it yields.
  3. If two independent events are measured separately, the total amount of information is the sum of the self-informations of the individual events.

The units of information in follow formula is 'bit':

I(x)=logâ¡2(1p(x))=âˆ’logâ¡2(p(x))I(x) = \log_{2}({1 \over p(x)}) = -\log_{2}({p(x)}) I(x)=log2â€‹(p(x)1â€‹)=âˆ’log2â€‹(p(x))

The concept of self-information is associated with variable values based on the observation of an information source. Consequently, multiple different values will be used to describe the same source.In order to avoid this situation, we introduce the concept of entropy.

# Entropy

Definition . The entropy (unit: bit/sig) of a discrete random variable XXX with probability distribution p(x)p(x)p(x) is denoted

H(X)â‰œâˆ‘xâˆˆÏ‡p(x)logâ¡21p(x)=E[logâ¡21p(x)]H(X) \triangleq \displaystyle\sum_{x \in \chi} p(x) \log_{2}{1\over p(x)} = \mathbb{E} [\log_{2}{1\over p(x)}] H(X)â‰œxâˆˆÏ‡âˆ‘â€‹p(x)log2â€‹p(x)1â€‹=E[log2â€‹p(x)1â€‹]

The unit of entropy is determined by the base of the logarithm with base-2 resulting in â€œbitsâ€ and the natural log (i.e., base-e) resulting in â€œnatsâ€.

The understanding of entropyï¼š

  1. Refers to the mathematical expectation of the self-information of various messages output by the information source, which is the average self-information of the source.
  2. Describe the average uncertainty of the information source XXX
  3. Describe the average amount of information carried by each source symbol

# joint entropy

Definition . The joint entropy (in bits) of a pair of (X,Y)âˆ½pX,Y(x,y)(X, Y) \backsim p_{X, Y}(x, y)(X,Y)âˆ½pX,Yâ€‹(x,y) is denoted

H(X,Y)â‰œâˆ‘(x,y)âˆˆXÃ—YpXY(x,y)logâ¡21pXY(x,y)=E[logâ¡21pXY(x,y)]H(X, Y) \triangleq \displaystyle\sum_{(x, y) \in \mathcal{X\times Y} } p_{XY}(x, y) \log_{2}{1\over p_{XY}(x, y)} = \mathbb{E} [\log_{2}{1\over p_{XY}(x, y)}] H(X,Y)â‰œ(x,y)âˆˆXÃ—Yâˆ‘â€‹pXYâ€‹(x,y)log2â€‹pXYâ€‹(x,y)1â€‹=E[log2â€‹pXYâ€‹(x,y)1â€‹]

Notice that this is identical to H(Z)H (Z)H(Z) with Z=(X,Y)Z = (X, Y)Z=(X,Y).

# conditional entropy

For a pair of (X,Y)âˆ½pX,Y(x,y)(X, Y ) \backsim p_{X,Y} (x, y)(X,Y)âˆ½pX,Yâ€‹(x,y), the conditional entropy (in bits) of YYY given XXX is denoted

H(Yâˆ£X)â‰œpX,Y(x,y)log21pYâˆ£X(yâˆ£x)=E[log21pYâˆ£X(yâˆ£x)]H(Y|X) \triangleq p_{X,Y}(x,y)log_{2}{1 \over p_{Y|X}(y|x)} = \mathbb{E}[log_{2}{1 \over p_{Y|X}(y|x)}] H(Yâˆ£X)â‰œpX,Yâ€‹(x,y)log2â€‹pYâˆ£Xâ€‹(yâˆ£x)1â€‹=E[log2â€‹pYâˆ£Xâ€‹(yâˆ£x)1â€‹]

conditional entropy H(Yâˆ£X)H(Y|X)H(Yâˆ£X) means the uncertainty of the YYY when the XXX is known.

# mutual information

Definition . For a pair of (X,Y)âˆ½pX,Y(x,y)(X, Y ) \backsim p_{X,Y} (x, y)(X,Y)âˆ½pX,Yâ€‹(x,y), the mutual information (in bits) between XXX and YYY is denoted

I(X;Y)â‰œâˆ‘(x,y)âˆˆXÃ—YpX,Y(x,y)log2pX,Y(x,y)PX(x)pY(y)=E[log2pX,Y(x,y)PX(x)pY(y)]I(X;Y) \triangleq \displaystyle\sum_{(x,y) \in \mathcal{X\times Y}}p_{X,Y}(x,y)log_{2}{p_{X,Y}(x,y) \over P_X(x)p_Y(y)} = \mathbb{E}[log_{2}{p_{X,Y}(x,y) \over P_X(x)p_Y(y)}] I(X;Y)â‰œ(x,y)âˆˆXÃ—Yâˆ‘â€‹pX,Yâ€‹(x,y)log2â€‹PXâ€‹(x)pYâ€‹(y)pX,Yâ€‹(x,y)â€‹=E[log2â€‹PXâ€‹(x)pYâ€‹(y)pX,Yâ€‹(x,y)â€‹]

# Lemma

Lemma . Basic properties of joint entropy and mutual information:

  1. (chain rule of entropy) H(X,Y)=H(X)+H(Yâˆ£X)H (X, Y) = H (X) + H (Y|X)H(X,Y)=H(X)+H(Yâˆ£X). If XXX and YYY are independent, H(X,Y)=H(X)+H(Y)H(X, Y) = H(X) + H(Y)H(X,Y)=H(X)+H(Y).
  2. The mutual information satisfies I(X;Y)=I(Y;X)I(X; Y) = I(Y ; X)I(X;Y)=I(Y;X) and

I(X;Y)=H(X)+H(Y)âˆ’H(X,Y)=H(X)âˆ’H(Xâˆ£Y)=H(Y)âˆ’H(Yâˆ£X)I(X;Y) = H(X) + H(Y) - H(X,Y) = H(X) -H(X|Y) = H(Y) - H(Y|X) I(X;Y)=H(X)+H(Y)âˆ’H(X,Y)=H(X)âˆ’H(Xâˆ£Y)=H(Y)âˆ’H(Yâˆ£X)

# References

  • https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/ æ¥µåŒ–ç¢¼
  • http://pfister.ee.duke.edu/courses/ecen655/polar.pdf

# åŒ—äº¬æ—¶é—´

å³ç„¶å·²ç»æœ‰äº†å›½é™…æ ‡å‡†æ—¶é—´ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¿˜è¦äº§ç”Ÿæˆ‘ä»¬è‡ªå·±çš„åŒ—äº¬æ—¶é—´ï¼Ÿ

å› ä¸ºå›½é™…æ ‡å‡†æ—¶é—´ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå®é™…çš„ç‰©ç†ä¿¡å·ï¼Œæ˜¯æ»åä¸€ä¸ªæœˆå‘å¸ƒçš„ä¸€ä¸ªçº¸é¢æ•°æ®ã€‚è€Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„æ˜¯çœŸæ­£èƒ½å®æ—¶åº”ç”¨çš„å®é™…ç‰©ç†ä¿¡å·ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥åŒ—äº¬æ—¶é—´åº”è¯¥æ˜¯å›½é™…æ ‡å‡†æ—¶é—´åœ¨ä¸­å›½çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå…·ä½“å®ç°ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸­å›½ç‰ˆçš„åè°ƒä¸–ç•Œæ—¶ã€‚
